subject: History
title: The Great Famine of 1315
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Great Famine of 1315 usable.

hook.text: Before the Black Death, Europe was already starving. Rain fell without stopping for two years.

buildup.text: Crops rotted in flooded fields. Livestock drowned. Grain prices soared to ten times normal levels.

discovery.text: Desperate people ate dogs, cats, and tree bark. Some chronicles report cannibalism in rural areas.

twist.text: The famine lasted seven years and killed millions. Europe's population hadn't recovered before plague struck.

climax.text: The Great Famine exposed how fragile medieval agriculture was. One bad climate shift and millions died.

punchline.text: Europe was broken before the plague even arrived.

quiz.question: What caused the Great Famine of 1315?
options: A volcanic winter from an eruption
Continuous heavy rain that destroyed crops for years
War that prevented farmers from planting
